text.p: IMC Global Inc, a fertilizer producer, said Friday its two-to-three year outlook remains "highly positive."

"Record-low world grain stocks, strong farm incomes due to high grain prices, and a continued increase in planted acres in North America are expected to further strengthen demand for crop nutrients," Wendell Bueche, chairman, said in a statement.
Accelerating global food needs can only be achieved through greater crop yields, which requires increased use of crop nutrients.

"Given the company's strong cash flow and access to capital, we intend to pursue future growth opportunities on a global scale," Bueche said. "Our recently-announced participation in the feasibility stage of a phosphate mining and processing venture in China's Yunnan Province is consistent with this objective."
IMC Global reported earnings for the first quarter ended September 30 of $0.31 a share before an $0.08 charge.
A year ago, it earned $0.35 a share.

First quarter earnings included $56.4 million in selling, general and administrative expenses, up from $46.0 million a year ago. The company said these costs were largely due to acquisitions and increased operating expenses associated with higher sales volume at IMC AgriBusiness.
"Potash revenues rose 11 percent primarily due to higher domestic and and export volumes," Bueche said.
Despite improved potash sales, gross margins fell 15 percent, largely due to increased production costs associated with an extended summer shutdown at four Canadian mines to reduce inventories.
"Conversely, phosphate sales declined 10 percent due to reduced international diammonium phosphate (DAP) volumes and lower phosphate rock revenues," Bueche said.
DAP exports to China, India and Japan were less than last year, but increased shipments of granular monoammonium phosphate and granular triple superphosphate softened the impact, he added.
Bueche said a later than normal fall harvest has delayed fall applications of nutrients, which contributed to first quarter results that were "essentially flat."
